column1: 0	Anarchism	"Anarchism''' is a [[political philosophy]] and [[Political movement|movement]] that is sceptical of [[authority]] and rejects all involuntary
column2: coercive forms of [[hierarchy]]. Anarchism calls for the abolition of the [[State (polity)|state]]
column3: which it holds to be undesirable
column4: unnecessary
column5: and harmful. As a historically [[left-wing]] movement
column6: placed on the farthest left of the [[political spectrum]]
column7: it is usually described alongside [[libertarian Marxism]] as the [[libertarian]] wing ([[libertarian socialism]]) of the [[socialist movement]]
column8: and has a strong historical association with [[anti-capitalism]] and [[socialism]].The [[history of anarchism]] goes back to [[prehistory]]
column9: when humans lived in anarchic societies long before the establishment of formal states
column11: or [[empire]]s. With the rise of organised hierarchical bodies
column12: [[scepticism]] toward authority also rose
column13: but it was not until the 19th century that a self-conscious political movement emerged. During the latter half of the 19th and the first decades of the 20th century
column14: the anarchist movement flourished in most parts of the world and had a significant role in workers' struggles for [[emancipation]]. Various [[anarchist schools of thought]] formed during this period. Anarchists have taken part in several revolutions
column15: most notably in the [[Spanish Civil War]]
column16: whose end marked the end of the [[classical era of anarchism]]. In the last decades of the 20th and into the 21st century
column17: the anarchist movement has been resurgent once more.

column6: and [[Praxis (process)|praxis]] have played a part in diverse areas of human society. Anarchism has been both defended and criticised; criticism of anarchism include claims that it is internally inconsistent

column1: 2	Albedo	Albedo''' ({{IPAc-en|æ|l|ˈ|b|iː|d|oʊ}}; {{etymology|la|albedo|whiteness}}) is the measure of the [[diffuse reflection]] of [[sunlight|solar radiation]] out of the total [[solar radiation]] and measured on a scale from 0
column2: corresponding to a [[black body]] that absorbs all incident radiation
column3: to 1
column4: corresponding to a body that reflects all incident radiation.Surface albedo is defined as the ratio of [[Radiosity (radiometry)|radiosity]] ''J''<sub>e</sub> to the [[irradiance]] ''E''<sub>e</sub> (flux per unit area) received by a surface.<ref>http://web.cse.ohio-state.edu/~parent.1/classes/782/Lectures/03_Radiometry.pdf</ref> The proportion reflected is not only determined by properties of the surface itself
column5: but also by the spectral and angular distribution of solar radiation reaching the Earth's surface.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |url=http://curry.eas.gatech.edu/Courses/6140/ency/Chapter9/Ency_Atmos/Reflectance_Albedo_Surface.pdf |title=Reflectance and albedo
column6: surface |encyclopedia=Encyclopedia of the Atmosphere |editor=J. R. Holton |editor2=J. A. Curry |last=Coakley |first=J. A. |publisher=Academic Press |year=2003|pages=1914–1923}}</ref> These factors vary with atmospheric composition
column7: geographic location and time (see [[position of the Sun]]). While bi-hemispherical [[reflectance]] is calculated for a single angle of incidence (i.e.
column8: for a given position of the Sun)
column9: albedo is the directional integration of reflectance over all solar angles in a given period. The temporal resolution may range from seconds (as obtained from flux measurements) to daily
column11: or annual averages.

column1: Unless given for a specific wavelength (spectral albedo)
column2: albedo refers to the entire spectrum of solar radiation.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Henderson-Sellers |first1=A. |last2=Wilson |first2=M. F.|year=1983 |quote=Albedo observations of the Earth's surface for climate research |jstor=37357 |journal=Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London A |volume=309 |issue=1508 |title=The Study of the Ocean and the Land Surface from Satellites |pages=285–294 |bibcode=1983RSPTA.309..285H |doi=10.1098/rsta.1983.0042|s2cid=122094064 }}</ref> Due to measurement constraints
column3: it is often given for the spectrum in which most solar energy reaches the surface (between 0.3 and 3 μm). This spectrum includes [[visible spectrum|visible light]] (0.4–0.7 μm)
column4: which explains why surfaces with a low albedo appear dark (e.g.
column5: trees absorb most radiation)
column6: whereas surfaces with a high albedo appear bright (e.g.
column7: snow reflects most radiation).

column3: such as on the [[Hectocotylus|hectocotyl (reproductive) arm]] of the [[octopus]]
column4: were disbelieved until the 19th century. He also influenced [[Judeo-Islamic philosophies (800–1400)]] during the [[Middle Ages]]
column5: as well as [[Christian theology]]
column6: especially the [[Neoplatonism]] of the [[Early Church]] and the [[Scholasticism|scholastic]] tradition of the [[Catholic Church]]. Aristotle was revered among medieval Muslim scholars as "The First Teacher"
column7: and among medieval Christians like [[Thomas Aquinas]] as simply "The Philosopher"
column8: while the poet [[Dante Alighieri|Dante]] called him “the master of those who know". His works contain the earliest known formal study of logic
column9: and were studied by medieval scholars such as [[Peter Abelard]] and [[John Buridan]].

column1: Aristotle's influence on logic continued well into the 19th century. In addition
column2: his [[Aristotelian ethics|ethics]]
column3: though always influential
column4: gained renewed interest with the modern advent of [[virtue ethics]].

column1: 11	Altruism	Altruism''' is the [[moral principle|principle]] and [[moral courage|moral practice]] of concern for [[happiness]] of other [[human kind|human beings]] or other animals
column2: resulting in a [[quality of life]] both [[material]] and [[spirituality|spiritual]]. It is a traditional [[virtue]] in many cultures and a core aspect of various religious traditions and secular worldviews
column3: though the concept of "others" toward whom concern should be directed can vary among cultures and religions. In an extreme case
column4: altruism may become a synonym of selflessness
column5: which is the opposite of [[selfishness]].The word "altruism" was popularized (and possibly coined) by the French philosopher [[Auguste Comte]] in French
column6: as ''altruisme''
column7: for an [[antonym]] of [[egoism]].<ref>{{cite web |title=altruism (n .) |url=http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=altruism |work=Online Etymology Dictionary |publisher=Douglas Harper |access-date=27 May 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Teske |first1=Nathan |title=Political Activists in America: The Identity Construction Model of Political Participation |date=2009|publisher=Pennsylvania State University Press |location=University Park
column8: Pa. |isbn=9780271035468|page=101|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7B38I2UEPa0C}}</ref> He derived it from the Italian ''altrui''
column9: which in turn was derived from Latin ''alteri''
column10: meaning "[[alterity|other people]]" or "somebody else".<ref>{{cite book|last1=Ciciloni|first1=Ferdinando|title=A Grammar of the Italian Language|date=1825|publisher=John Murray|location=London|page=[https://archive.org/details/agrammaritalian00cicigoog/page/n81 64]|url=https://archive.org/details/agrammaritalian00cicigoog}}</ref>

column1: Altruism in [[Biology|biological]] observations in field populations of the day organisms is an individual performing an action which is at a cost to themselves (e.g.
column2: pleasure and quality of life
column3: time
column4: probability of survival or reproduction)
column5: but benefits
column6: either directly or indirectly
column7: another individual
column8: without the expectation of reciprocity or compensation for that action. Steinberg suggests a definition for altruism in the clinical setting
column9: that is "intentional and voluntary actions that aim to enhance the welfare of another person in the absence of any quid pro quo external rewards".<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Altruism in medicine: its definition
column11: and dilemmas|last = Steinberg|first = David|date = 2010|journal = Cambridge Quarterly of Healthcare Ethics |volume=19 |issue=2 |pages=249–57|doi = 10.1017/s0963180109990521|pmid = 20226108|s2cid = 30534335}}</ref> In one sense
column12: the opposite of altruism is [[Spite (sentiment)|spite]]; a spiteful action harms another with no self-benefit.

column1: Altruism can be distinguished from feelings of [[loyalty]]
column2: in that whilst the latter is predicated upon social relationships
column3: altruism does not consider relationships. Much debate exists as to whether ''"true"'' altruism is possible in human psychology. The theory of [[psychological egoism]] suggests that no act of sharing
column4: helping or sacrificing can be described as truly altruistic
column5: as the actor may receive an intrinsic reward in the form of personal [[gratification]]. The validity of this argument depends on whether [[Motivation#Incentive theories: intrinsic and extrinsic motivation|intrinsic rewards]] qualify as "benefits".

column1: The term ''[[altruism (ethics)|altruism]]'' may also refer to an ethical doctrine that claims that individuals are morally obliged to benefit others. Used in this sense
column2: it is usually contrasted with [[ethical egoism|egoism]]
column3: which claims individuals are morally obligated to serve themselves first. [[Effective altruism]] is the use of evidence and reason to determine the most effective ways to benefit others.

Many of the [[Disney animated features]] are examples of full animation, as are non-Disney works, ''[[The Secret of NIMH]]'' (US, 1982), ''[[The Iron Giant]]'' (US, 1999), and ''[[Nocturna (Film)|Nocturna]]'' (Spain, 2007). Fully animated films are animated at 24 frames per second, with a combination of animation on ones and twos, meaning that drawings can be held for one frame out of 24 or two frames out of 24.{{sfn|Laybourne|1998|pp=25–26}}
28	Animation	[[Limited animation]]''' involves the use of less detailed or more stylized drawings and methods of movement usually a choppy or "skippy" movement animation.{{sfn|Beckerman|2003|p=142}} Limited animation uses fewer drawings per second, thereby limiting the fluidity of the animation. This is a more economic technique. Pioneered by the artists at the American studio [[United Productions of America]],{{sfn|Beckerman|2003|pp=54–55}} limited animation can be used as a method of stylized artistic expression, as in ''[[Gerald McBoing-Boing]]'' (US, 1951), ''[[Yellow Submarine (1968 film)|Yellow Submarine]]'' (UK, 1968), and certain [[anime]] produced in Japan.{{sfn|Ledoux|1997|p=24, 29}} Its primary use, however, has been in producing cost-effective animated content for media for television (the work of Hanna-Barbera,{{sfn|Lawson|Persons|2004|p=82}} [[Filmation]],{{sfn|Solomon|1989|p=241}} and other TV animation studios{{sfn|Lawson|Persons|2004|p=xxi}}) and later the [[Internet]] ([[web cartoon]]s).
29	Animation	Rotoscoping''' is a technique patented by [[Max Fleischer]] in 1917 where animators trace live-action movement, frame by frame.{{sfn|Crafton|1993|p=158}} The source film can be directly copied from actors' outlines into animated drawings,{{sfn|Laybourne|1998|pp=163–64}} as in ''[[The Lord of the Rings (1978 film)|The Lord of the Rings]]'' (US, 1978), or used in a stylized and expressive manner, as in ''[[Waking Life]]'' (US, 2001) and ''[[A Scanner Darkly (film)|A Scanner Darkly]]'' (US, 2006). Some other examples are ''[[Fire and Ice (1983 film)|Fire and Ice]]'' (US, 1983), ''[[Heavy Metal (film)|Heavy Metal]]'' (1981), and ''[[The Flowers of Evil (manga)|Aku no Hana]]'' (Japan, 2013).

column1: 37	Animal Farm	''Animal Farm''''' is a [[Satire|satirical]] [[allegory|allegorical]] [[novella]] by [[George Orwell]]
column2: first published in England on 17 August 1945.{{sfn|Bynum|2012}}{{sfn|12 Things You|2015}} The book tells the story of a group of farm animals who rebel against their human farmer
column3: hoping to create a society where the animals can be equal
column4: free
column5: and happy. Ultimately

column8: under the dictatorship of a pig named [[Napoleon (Animal Farm)|Napoleon]].According to Orwell
column9: the [[fable]] reflects events leading up to the [[Russian Revolution of 1917]] and then on into the [[History of the Soviet Union (1927–53)|Stalinist era]] of the [[Soviet Union]].{{sfn|Gcse English Literature}}{{sfn|Meija|2002}}  Orwell
column11: {{sfn|Orwell |2014 |p=23}} was a critic of [[Joseph Stalin]] and hostile to Moscow-directed [[Stalinism]]

column19: {{sfn|Davison|2000|p=}} and in his essay "[[Why I Write]]" (1946)

[[tetrapod]] [[vertebrate]]s of the [[Class (biology)|class]] '''Amphibia'''. All living amphibians belong to the group [[Lissamphibia]]. They inhabit a wide variety of [[habitat]]s
column3: with most species living within [[terrestrial animal|terrestrial]]
column4: [[fossorial]]
column5: [[arboreal]] or freshwater [[aquatic ecosystems]]. Thus amphibians typically start out as [[larva]]e living in water
column6: but some species have developed behavioural adaptations to bypass this.The young generally undergo [[metamorphosis]] from larva with gills to an adult air-breathing form with [[lung]]s. Amphibians use their skin as a secondary respiratory surface and some small terrestrial [[salamander]]s and [[frog]]s lack lungs and rely entirely on their skin. They are superficially similar to [[lizard]]s but
column7: along with mammals and birds
column8: [[reptile]]s are [[amniote]]s and do not require water bodies in which to breed. With their complex reproductive needs and permeable skins
column9: amphibians are often [[ecological indicator]]s; in recent decades there has been a dramatic [[decline in amphibian populations]] for many species around the globe.

column1: The earliest amphibians [[evolution of tetrapods|evolved]] in the [[Devonian]] period from [[sarcopterygian]] fish with lungs and bony-limbed fins
column2: features that were helpful in adapting to dry land. They diversified and became dominant during the [[Carboniferous]] and [[Permian]] periods
column3: but were later displaced by reptiles and other vertebrates. Over time
column4: amphibians shrank in size and decreased in diversity
column5: leaving only the modern subclass Lissamphibia.

column1: The three modern orders of amphibians are [[Anura (frog)|Anura]] (the frogs)
column2: [[Urodela]] (the salamanders)
column3: and [[caecilian|Apoda]] (the caecilians). The number of known amphibian species is approximately 8
column5: of which nearly 90% are frogs. The smallest amphibian (and vertebrate) in the world is a frog from [[New Guinea]] (''[[Paedophryne amauensis]]'') with a length of just {{convert|7.7|mm|in|abbr=on}}. The largest living amphibian is the {{convert|1.8|m|0|abbr=on}} [[South China giant salamander]] (''Andrias sligoi'')
column6: but this is dwarfed by the extinct {{convert|9|m|0|abbr=on}} ''[[Prionosuchus]]'' from the [[Guadalupian|middle Permian]] of Brazil. The study of amphibians is called [[batrachology]]
column7: while the study of both reptiles and amphibians is called [[herpetology]].

column1: The first major groups of amphibians developed in the [[Devonian]] period
column2: around 370 million years ago
column3: from [[Sarcopterygii|lobe-finned fish]] which were similar to the modern [[coelacanth]] and [[lungfish]].<ref name="evoamphib">{{cite web |url=http://sci.waikato.ac.nz/evolution/AnimalEvolution.shtml#evolutionofamphibian |title=Evolution of amphibians |publisher=University of Waikato: Plant and animal evolution |access-date=September 30
column4: 2012}}</ref> These ancient lobe-finned fish had evolved multi-jointed leg-like fins with digits that enabled them to crawl along the sea bottom. Some fish had developed primitive lungs that help them breathe air when the stagnant pools of the Devonian swamps were low in oxygen. They could also use their strong fins to hoist themselves out of the water and onto dry land if circumstances so required. Eventually
column5: their bony fins would [[evolution|evolve]] into limbs and they would become the ancestors to all [[tetrapod]]s
column6: including modern amphibians
column7: reptiles
column8: birds
column9: and [[mammal]]s. Despite being able to crawl on land
column10: many of these prehistoric [[tetrapodomorph]] fish still spent most of their time in the water. They had started to develop lungs
column11: but still breathed predominantly with gills.<ref name="Carroll">{{cite book |title=Patterns of Evolution
column12: as Illustrated by the Fossil Record |last=Carroll |first=Robert L. |editor=Hallam

column3: a neck

column5: ''[[Eusthenopteron]]''.<ref name="evoamphib" /> Amphibians evolved adaptations that allowed them to stay out of the water for longer periods. Their lungs improved and their skeletons became heavier and stronger
column6: better able to support the weight of their bodies on land.<!--'cope with the increased gravitational effect of life' - The gravitational force is effectively the same on the surface of the land as in the sea; however

R. |year=1979 |title=Evolution of the tetrapod ear: an analysis and reinterpretation |journal=Biological Journal of the Linnean Society |volume=11 |issue=1 |pages=19–76 |doi=10.1111/j.1095-8312.1979.tb00027.x |url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/230169547 }}</ref> An affinity between the amphibians and the [[teleost]] fish is the multi-folded structure of the teeth and the paired [[Occipital bone|supra-occipital bones]] at the back of the head

There were no other tetrapods on the land and the amphibians were at the top of the food chain

column14: most still had a long tapering body and strong tail.<ref name="Spoczynska">{{cite book |title=Fossils: A Study in Evolution |last=Spoczynska |first=J. O. I. |year=1971 |publisher=Frederick Muller Ltd |isbn=978-0-584-10093-8 |pages=120–125 }}</ref> They were the top land predators

column1: As they evolved from lunged fish
column2: amphibians had to make certain adaptations for living on land
column3: including the need to develop new means of locomotion. In the water
column4: the sideways thrusts of their tails had propelled them forward
column5: but on land
column6: quite different mechanisms were required. Their vertebral columns
column7: limbs
column8: limb girdles and musculature needed to be strong enough to raise them off the ground for locomotion and feeding. Terrestrial adults discarded their [[lateral line]] systems and adapted their sensory systems to receive stimuli via the medium of the air. They needed to develop new methods to regulate their body heat to cope with fluctuations in ambient temperature. They developed behaviours suitable for reproduction in a terrestrial environment. Their skins were exposed to harmful [[ultraviolet]] rays that had previously been absorbed by the water. The skin changed to become more protective and prevent excessive water loss.{{sfn | Dorit | Walker | Barnes | 1991 | pp=843–859 }}

52	Assistive technology	Assistive technology''' (AT) is a term for assistive, adaptive, and rehabilitative devices for [[Disability|people with disabilities]] or the elderly population. People with disabilities often have difficulty performing [[activities of daily living]] (ADLs) independently, or even with assistance. ADLs are self-care activities that include toileting, mobility (ambulation), eating, bathing, dressing, grooming, and personal device care. Assistive technology can ameliorate the effects of disabilities that limit the ability to perform ADLs. Assistive technology promotes greater independence by enabling people to perform tasks they were formerly unable to accomplish, or had great difficulty accomplishing, by providing enhancements to, or changing methods of interacting with, the [[technology]] needed to accomplish such tasks. For example, wheelchairs provide independent mobility for those who cannot walk, while [[assistive eating devices]] can enable people who cannot feed themselves to do so. Due to assistive technology, people with disability have an opportunity of a more positive and easygoing lifestyle, with an increase in "social participation," "security and control," and a greater chance to "reduce institutional costs without significantly increasing household expenses."<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Parant|first1=Aymeric|last2=Schiano-Lomoriello|first2=Sandrine|last3=Marchan|first3=Francis|date=October 2017|title=How would I live with a disability? 93	Amateur astronomy	GOTO telescopes''' have become more popular since the 1980s as technology has improved and prices have been reduced.  With these computer-driven telescopes, the user typically enters the name of the item of interest and the mechanics of the telescope point the telescope towards that item automatically.  They have several notable advantages for amateur astronomers intent on [[research]].  For example, GOTO telescopes tend to be faster for locating items of interest than star hopping, allowing more time for studying of the object.  GOTO also allows manufacturers to add equatorial tracking to mechanically simpler alt-azimuth telescope mounts, allowing them to produce an overall less expensive product. GOTO telescopes usually have to be calibrated using alignment stars in order to provide accurate tracking and positioning. However, several telescope manufacturers have recently developed telescope systems that are calibrated with the use of built-in GPS, decreasing the time it takes to set up a telescope at the start of an observing session.

After British General [[John Burgoyne|Burgoyne]] surrendered at the [[Battles of Saratoga]] in October 1777
column7: Howe's 1777–1778 [[Philadelphia campaign]] captured that city. Washington retreated to [[Valley Forge]] during the winter of 1777–1778 where Prussian allied General [[Friedrich Wilhelm von Steuben|von Steuben]] drilled the largely untrained [[Continental Army]] into an organized fighting unit.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Editors|first=History com|title=How Valley Forge Transformed the Continental Army Into a Fighting Force|url=https://www.history.com/topics/american-revolution/valley-forge|access-date=2021-07-07|website=HISTORY|language=en}}</ref>

column3: not Britain. Although talks on a formal alliance began in late 1776
